author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request does not meet the following guidelines for auto-merging:

- Name does not meet all of the following: starts with a capital letter, ASCII alphanumerics only, ends in lowercase
- Name is not at least five characters long

Note that the guidelines are only required for the pull request to be merged automatically. However, it is **strongly recommended** to follow them, since otherwise the pull request needs to be manually reviewed and merged by a human.

---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

this is a julia wrapper for a library written in C:
http://reasoning.cs.ucla.edu/sdd/

this is why the name of the package does not pass the auto-merge guideline checks.

https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/v1/creating-packages/index.html#Package-naming-guidelines-1

Guideline 1:
> Avoid jargon. In particular, avoid acronyms unless there is minimal possibility of confusion.
> It's ok to say USA if you're talking about the USA.
> It's not ok to say PMA, even if you're talking about positive mental attitude.

Guideline 4:
> Err on the side of clarity, even if clarity seems long-winded to you.
> RandomMatrices is a less ambiguous name than RndMat or RMT, even though the latter are shorter.

That being said, I do acknowledge that the guideline 6 says the following:
> CPLEX.jl wraps the CPLEX library, which can be identified easily in a web search.
> MATLAB.jl provides an interface to call the MATLAB engine from within Julia.

But I think that naming the Julia package after the library really only makes sense if the library is one of the first search results. For example, if you search for `CPLEX`, then the IBM web page for the CPLEX Optimizer is the first result. And if you search for `MATLAB`, then the Mathworks web page for MATLAB is the first result.

But if you search for `SDD`, then the C library doesn't show up in the first few pages.

So I think that guidelines 1 and 4 are important here.

How about one of the following:
- `SententialDecisionDiagrams.jl`
- `SDDiagrams.jl`

Thanks for having a look at this!

I am not sure I can agree with the point you are making about the search results.

If I look at point six of the guidelines, it says:

> 6. Packages that wrap external libraries or programs should be named after those libraries or programs.

It does not really say anything about being easily identifiable in a web search, this is only mentioned in one of the examples. Moreover, if I google (in an anonymous session) "sdd.jl" the first hit is the github repo.

My main point is that when it comes to naming Julia packages, we should prioritize clarity. By which I mean, the name alone should give you some sense of what the package is about.

If you ask the average Julia user what `SDD` is, I doubt they will say "Sentential Decision Diagrams".

cc: @StefanKarpinski @fredrikekre @KristofferC and the other registry maintainers.

It doesn't seem like there is a lot of support for this name. I would highly recommend a more descriptive name.

Personally, I can't merge this PR with the current name of `SDD`.

Bump.

I cannot merge this pull request with the current name `SDD`.

I’ll leave this open for two more weeks. If another registry maintainer has not merged it by then, I’ll close this.

Okay, no worries. I changed the name to SententialDecisionDiagrams in the Project.toml file. Is there anything else that I should change? Also, I accidentally made a new pull request.

Thanks for taking care of this!

title: New package: SDD v0.1.0
